value: Carved pearwood prayer nut or prayer bead, with silver mounts.

Carved pearwood, with silver mounts. The two hemispherical parts are hinged together and fastened with a silver clasp. The outsides are carved with pierced 'flamboyant' tracery, and both ends have a silver mount and ring. The inside surfaces have minute figure carvings: one is of the Virgin, seated, holding the Child on her left knee with her left hand and offering a fruit with her right hand. Her hair reaches down to her waist. The edge of the little roundel is cusped. The other carving is of St Cecilia seated on the right playing an organ, set obliquely to the picture plane, and pumped by an angel on the left. St Cecilia's hair falls in ringlets to her waist.

summary_title: Treasured Possessions from the Renaissance to the Enlightenment

notes: Ref. See no. 663, p. 44, illustrated p. 45. This is so identical to the Marlay acquisition it could be the same bead.

summary_title: Medieval Ivories and Works of Art, The Thomson Collection at the Art Gallery of Toronto
notes: Cf. p. 140-1, two boxwood prayer beads with carved scenes inside. Attribution to Flanders, late 15th or early 16th century. D. 6.4 and 7.6 cm. Text p. 138, no. 49 with the Queen of Sheba before Solomon and the Adoration of the Magi, and no. 50 with the Gates of Heaven and Hell, and the Trinity surrounded by angels. Bibliography provided.

summary_title: A Rothschild Renaissance, Treasures from the Waddesdon Bequest
notes: Cf. Two larger and more intricately carved prayer nuts or beads in the British Museum.  Pages 162-7, Boxwood prayer nut 1, length 13.2 cm, inv. WB236, which has two outward folding doors over the upper compartment and a circular door over the lower part, respectively having within a Crucifixion, and Christ bearing the Cross; with further scenes on the doors in low relief. Pages 168-71, Boxwood prayer nut 2, length  9.7 cm. inv. WB238, which has the Adoration of the Magi in the upper part and a Pietà in the lower part. Both are attributed to the Northern Netherlands and dated c. 1510-25. See p. 170, Fig. 3, a portrait of an fidentified male sitter holding what appears to be a prayer nut in his right hand. Rijksmuseum, Amsterdam, inv. SK-A03838.

summary_title: Stories of the Rose. The Making of then Rosary in the Middle Ages
